title: R44526
content: The FY2017 judiciary appropriations overview includes key actions such as request submission, hearings, markups, and enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017. The budget request was for $7.58 billion, with $6.99 billion in discretionary funds and $0.59 billion in mandatory funding for judges' salaries and benefits. The FY2017 judiciary budget request was for $7.58 billion, including $6.99 billion in discretionary funds and $0.59 billion in mandatory funding for judges' salaries and benefits. The House Appropriations Committee recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary, with mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits as required by law. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees recommended $7.55 billion and $7.58 billion, respectively, in funds for the judiciary in the FY2017 FSGG bill, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits as required by law. No amendments were offered during the markups. On June 16, 2016, the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $7.58 billion in funds for the judiciary in the FY2017 FSGG bill. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-0. No amendments were offered related to the judiciary. On July 5, the House agreed to a structured rule for consideration of the bill. One amendment related to the judiciary was made in order, reducing funding by $1 million. The amended bill was agreed to on July 7 with a vote of 239-185. No further action was taken on the bill before the start of FY2017. H.R. 5485, as amended, was agreed to on July 7 with a vote of 239-185. No further action was taken on the bill before the start of FY2017. Judicial branch activities were funded through continuing appropriations resolutions until the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017. The act provided $7.5 billion for the judiciary, an increase of $176.2 million from FY2016. The judiciary's funding for FY2015 and FY2014 saw increases and decreases compared to their requests. A funding gap in FY2014 led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days. The judiciary's appropriations make up about 0.2% of the total budget. The CR (P.L. 113-46) was enacted on October 17, 2013, providing funding until January 15, 2014. A consolidated appropriations bill (P.L. 113-76) on January 17, 2014, allocated $7.039 billion for the judiciary for FY2014. The judiciary's budget comprises 0.2% of total budget authority, with the Supreme Court's accounts totaling 1%. The Salaries and Expenses account for U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services is the largest, covering approximately 72% of the total FY2017 enacted level. The Salaries and Expenses account for the U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services is the largest, covering salaries of judges and necessary court expenses. Defender Services and Court Security are also significant accounts. Other parts of the judiciary budget fund various courts and administrative offices. The judiciary budget funds various courts and administrative offices, including the U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services. Non-appropriated funds, mainly from court filing fees, help offset expenses within the judiciary. Some funds are carried forward from year to year and are considered "unencumbered." Non-appropriated funds, primarily from court filing fees, offset expenses in the Salaries and Expenses accounts of various courts. These funds, considered "unencumbered," result from savings in the judiciary's financial plan. Encumbered funds are used for specific delayed expenses. The judiciary has "encumbered" funds for specific purposes, used when expenses are delayed. Cost-containment efforts focus on office space rental, personnel expenses, information technology, and operating costs. Judge Gibbons emphasized ongoing cost-containment initiatives since 2004, including shared administrative services and reducing space footprint. Judge Gibbons stated that the budget request reflects cost-containment policies, with a focus on shared administrative services and reducing space footprint. Efforts to achieve a 3% reduction in total space have resulted in $5.8 million in rent savings. The judiciary is reevaluating methodologies for cost savings accounting in response to a GAO report. Security concerns have prompted improvements in judicial security measures. The judiciary has reached 30% of its goal to reduce total space by 3%, saving $5.8 million in rent. Efforts to enhance judicial security have been driven by past incidents, leading to collaboration with the U.S. Marshals Service for protective measures. The judiciary collaborates with the U.S. Marshals Service to enhance security for judges and court personnel, including perimeter security at selected courthouses. The pilot program, initiated in FY2009, has been evaluated for improvements, with the judiciary reimbursing USMS for protective services. The judiciary collaborates with the U.S. Marshals Service for security functions at courthouses in various cities. The Judicial Conference recommended creating new federal judgeships, but no final action has been taken on the bills introduced. Appellate judgeships have remained at 179 since 1990 despite a 40% increase in case filings. Legislation introduced in the House and Senate to address the request, but no final action taken before the 114th Congress adjourned. Since 1990, appellate judgeships remained at 179 despite a 40% increase in case filings. The FY2017 judiciary budget request is $7.53 billion, with the Supreme Court requesting $94.5 million, a 7.0% increase over FY2016. The House and Senate provided the full request in their bills. The court's budget of $94.5 million is divided into two accounts: Salaries and Expenses of $79.3 million and Care of the Building and Grounds of $14.9 million, representing a 7.0% increase over FY2016. The court, with 12 judges, has jurisdiction over various cases including patents, trademarks, international trade, and federal claims. The FY2017 budget request is $33.1 million, a 2.1% decrease from FY2016. The court also has exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions against the United States and certain civil actions related to import transactions and enforcement of trade laws. The FY2017 request of $20.50 million is a 1.7% increase over FY2016. The FY2017 funding request for civil actions related to import transactions and enforcement of trade laws is $20.50 million, a 1.7% increase over FY2016. The total FY2017 funding request for courts covers 12 courts of appeals and 94 district judicial courts. The total funding request is $7,141.5 million, divided among various expenses including salaries, court security, defender services, and fees of jurors and commissioners. The FY2017 funding request for this account is $5,469.8 million, a 2.8% increase over FY2016. The House-passed bill provided $7,104.7 million and the Senate committee-reported bill provided $7,135.8 million. P.L. 115-31 provides $7,076.9 million. The FY2017 request for this account is $5,469.8 million, an increase of 2.8% over the FY2016 enacted level. The Vaccine Injury Compensation Program funds a federal no-fault program to address vaccine tort liability claims. The FY2017 request for the program is $6.3 million, a 3.5% increase over the FY2016 enacted level. The account for protective services in federal facilities ensures the safety of judicial officers, employees, and visitors. The account under P.L. 115-31 provides $6.5 million for protective services, security systems, and equipment needs in federal facilities. The funding is mainly for court security officers under the Judicial Facility Security Program. Additionally, it funds federal public defender and community defender organizations, as well as compensation for defense counsel appointed by federal courts. The FY2017 request is $1,056.3 million, with P.L. 115-31 providing $1,044.6 million. The FY2017 budget request for indigent individuals is $1,056.3 million, with P.L. 115-31 providing $1,044.6 million. This account also funds fees for jurors and compensation for jury and land commissioners. The AOUSC provides administrative and IT services to the U.S. courts, with a FY2017 request of $87.7 million. The Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts (AOUSC) provides management, program, and IT services to the U.S. courts. The FY2017 budget request for AOUSC is $87.7 million, with a 2.4% increase over FY2016. The Federal Judicial Center conducts research and education for the judiciary, with a FY2017 request of $28.3 million, a 2.2% increase. The U.S. Sentencing Commission sets sentencing policies for the federal criminal justice system, with a FY2017 request of $18.2 million, a 3.3% increase. The U.S. Sentencing Commission's FY2017 request is $18.2 million, a 3.3% increase over FY2016. The House-passed bill provided $18.0 million, the Senate committee-reported bill provided $18.2 million, and P.L. 115-31 provides $18.1 million. This mandatory account funds retirement benefits for judges and their families, with a FY2017 request of $161.0 million. P.L. 115-31 also includes provisions for salaries, expenses, and transfers between judiciary appropriations accounts. The FY2017 request for retirement benefits is $161.0 million, fully funded by P.L. 115-31. The bill includes provisions for salaries, expenses, transfers between judiciary accounts, official reception expenses, repairs under $100,000, court security pilot program, and extension of temporary judgeships.
